Award.AwardTitle: Investigating Lithospheric Evolution Beneath the Southern and Northeastern United States
Award.AbstractNarration:
Throughout Earth?s history, the tectonic plates that make up the lithosphere have converged to form super-continents and then pulled apart over time-scales of hundreds of millions of years. The southern U.S. near the Gulf Coast and the eastern U.S. bordering the Atlantic experienced two cycles of super-continent formation and break-up. These episodes of collision and rifting altered the crust and mantle lithosphere of the North American plate, thickening these layers in some regions, thinning them in others, and producing distinctive structures by aligning mineral grains and melting small amounts of rock. In this project we will use earthquake waves to construct three-dimensional models of the crust and mantle lithosphere, and we will interpret these models to better understand how continental collision and rifting affect continental lithosphere.

The goal of this work is to improve resolution of crust and mantle structure in the southern and eastern U.S. in order to better understand lithospheric evolution and modification through the last Wilson cycle. The southern and eastern margins of the North America continent experienced two complete Wilson cycles of orogeny and rifting, leaving varied signatures of deformation and magmatism in the crust and mantle lithosphere of these regions. However, many aspects of crust and mantle structure remain poorly known at the scales relevant to distinguishing the effects of orogeny, rifting, and other processes such as hotspot interaction. Using data from the NSF EarthScope USArray/Transportable Array (TA), now completed in the contiguous U.S., we propose to image crust and mantle seismic structure in new detail. We will focus on two regions: one spanning the southern craton edge, the entire Ouachita orogeny and the Gulf of Mexico coastal plain, and the other containing the eastern craton edge, the central and northern Appalachians, and the Atlantic coast. We will use seismic data from TA stations, supplemented by other temporary and permanent broadband stations, to image crustal and mantle discontinuities using Sp and Ps receiver functions, construct 3-D anisotropic models based on Rayleigh wave, Love wave and shear-wave-splitting analyses, and we will integrate these data and methods through joint analyses and inversions. The seismic models will be used constrain the style and geometry of deformation in the crust and mantle lithosphere due to the last episodes of orogeny and rifting. This interpretation will be guided by geological and active source indicators of deformation in the shallow crust and by the type and age of magmatism across the region, bearing in mind that some facets of crust and mantle structure may reflect events that predated or followed the last cycle of orogeny and continental rifting. Variations in the impact of orogeny and rifting on the lithosphere will be compared between and within the study regions. The proposed project will support the education and career development of graduate students at the University of Houston and at Brown. It will also contribute to undergraduate senior theses, lab exercises and group research projects in undergraduate and graduate courses, and to science outreach activities with local public schools. Students from diverse backgrounds will be recruited to participate in this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The southern and eastern North American continent experienced similar orogenic and rifting tectonic events: the Ouachita orogeny and the opening of the Gulf of Mexico in the south and the Appalachian orogeny and the opening of the Atlantic Ocean in the east.  It is also known that hotspots play an essential role in opening the Atlantic Ocean. However, magmatism occurred in the southern and eastern U.S. at tens of million years ago, a long time after the continental rifting, whose mechanism is poorly understood. The goal of this project is to better understand lithospheric evolution and modification through the most recent continental collision and rifting by developing high-resolution, 3-D seismic velocity models in the southern and northeastern North America.

We have processed surface wave data recorded at the USArray/Transportable Array (TA) stations and constructed shear wave velocity models for the crust and upper mantle in two regions. One region spans from Texas to Alabama including the Ouachita orogeny and the Gulf of Mexico coastal plain, and the other from West Virginia to Maine containing the central and northern Appalachians and the Atlantic coast.  Vsv (vertically polarized shear wave) models are derived from Rayleigh waves, and Vsh (horizontally polarized shear wave) models are derived from Love waves.  Radial anisotropy (the discrepancy between Vsv and Vsh) models are developed from both types of surface waves. These models have the lateral resolution less than 100 km, much higher than previous models, especially for radial anisotropy. Variations in velocity and anisotropy reflect changes in thermal and compositional status as well as the style and geometry of deformation in the crust and mantle lithosphere.  They allow us to understand how the lithosphere has been modified  by previous orogenic, rifting, and hotspot activities.

In the shallow crust of the northern Gulf Coast region, low velocity appears in the coastal plain to the south of Ouachita front due to thick sediments. In the middle and lower crust, the Ouachita belt in Texas is characterized by a seaward dipping high-velocity band,  which is not observed in the east Ouachita, indicating structural variations along the orogen. Strong positive radial anisotropy (Vsh>Vsv) is largely confined in the coastal plain in the lower crust, limiting the crustal extension during opening the Gulf of Mexico to the Ouachita and Appalachian front. Velocity variations in the mantle do not follow geological boundaries on the surface. A high-velocity lithosphere to ~75 km depth exists across the entire region except at a few local uplifts (Uvalde, Sabine, Benton), the Arkansas River Valley, and the Mississippi Valley Graben. Significantly low velocities are imaged in southernmost Texas and at the Uvalde, Monroe, and Jackson uplifts, where Cretaceous (65-145 Ma) igneous rocks are found.  These slow anomalies correlate with high surface heat flow and strong positive radial anisotropy, indicating hot and weak mantle blocks.  The southernmost anomaly aligns with a high gravity lineation in the Gulf of Mexico and probably played an important role in opening the gulf during the Mesozoic.

The 3-D anisotropic velocity model in northeastern America reveals substantial lateral variations in the upper mantle. The North American craton and the Grenville orogeny are primarily characterized by high velocities (> 4.6 km/s) above 100 km.  A significantly low-velocity anomaly (3-4%) is imaged in New England and New York, which is referred to as NAA (Northern Appalachian Anomaly).  Two other slow anomalies appear at the depths of 140-240 km, one from southeast Pennsylvania to the Atlantic coast and the other at the border of northern Virginia and West Virginia, which are referred to as CAA (Central Appalachian Anomaly).  The variations of the radial anisotropy model correlate well with those in the shear velocity model.  Both the NAA and CAA are associated with positive radial anisotropy (Vsh>Vsv), indicating dominant horizontal asthenospheric flow. The NAA roughly aligns with the track of the Great Meteor hotspot and the CAA is on the track of a hidden hotspot, reflecting hotspot influence on the formation of the anomalies.  The base of the continental lithosphere could have developed channels or cavities due to thermal erosion by interacting with a hotspot. The slow anomalies are consistent with hot asthenosphere that has been dragged by plate motion into the lithosphere cavities caused by previous hotspots.  This mechanism can explain both the slow velocities and positive radial anisotropy at the NAA and CAA.  We propose that low-velocity anomalies at passive margins do not occur randomly but rather where the lithosphere has been eroded by prior interactions with hotspots.
